docs.lead_paragraph: A variety of consumer-focused articles appear daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.
docs.abstract: The Fed could get responsibility for a new consumer financial protection agency, how complaints about Toyotas stack up and other consumer-focused items from Tuesday's Times.

byline.original: By JACKIE CALMES and DAVID HERSZENHORN

docs.lead_paragraph: Lionel Shriver’s new book creates a harrowing picture of the fallout that the current health care and insurance system can have upon regular, middle-class families.

docs.lead_paragraph: A bankruptcy judge agreed that account holders who withdrew their original investment did not suffer losses, no matter what their last statement said.

headline.main: Madoff Judge Endorses Trustee’s Rule on Losses
headline.print_headline: Madoff Judge Endorses Trustee’s Rule on Losses

headline.sub: Why haven't negative polls killed health care reform?

docs.lead_paragraph: We're smack dab in the middle of tax season, and I am done. I spent a couple of Saturdays gathering all of my bank statements and other documents, making post-closing general journal entries, and printing out financial statements to deliver to my C.P.A. for both our corporate and personal income tax returns. As my Canadian father would say, my books are now tickety-boo (translation: in perfect working order).

headline.main: Finding Something to Like About April 15

docs.abstract: While I don't enjoy writing checks to the I.R.S., I have to admit that tax season offers an opportunity to take care of tasks that I've been putting off for 12 months.
docs.snippet: While I don't enjoy writing checks to the I.R.S., I have to admit that tax season offers an opportunity to take care of tasks that I've been putting off for 12 months.
